context: Racing against the player's own ghost data from previous acts. A confrontation with who you used to be.

lines.text: The track loads something different this time.
Not an opponent. Not a rival. Not a stranger in a fast car with something to prove.
You.

Ghost data. Your ghost data. Recorded during Act 1 — every steering input, every throttle blip, every brake point. A transparent replica of your car, running the exact line you ran when you first came to Nova Pacifica.
You watch yourself drive. The Act 1 version. Sloppy. Fast, but reckless. Braking too late, turning in too early. Chasing the apex like it owed you money.
You were so hungry back then. You can see it in the data — the aggression, the desperation. Every millisecond clawed from the track by force, not finesse.
You line up beside yourself. The ghost shimmers — translucent, indifferent, locked in its replay. It doesn't know you're here. It doesn't know what comes next.
Green light. You both launch.
The ghost is fast. Recklessly, terrifyingly fast. It throws itself into corners with an abandon that makes your stomach drop just watching. No margin. No reserve. All or nothing.
But you're better now. Not faster — better. Your lines are cleaner. Your braking is precise. You carry speed where the ghost scrubs it off. You flow where the ghost fights.
You pass yourself on turn six. The ghost doesn't react. It can't. It's just data. Just a memory of someone you used to be.
You beat the Act 1 ghost. The transparent car fades at the finish line like steam.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: You beat your old time by four seconds.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: You were so hungry back then.
New ghost. Act 2 data.
This one is different. Smoother. Faster in the straights because the car was better by then — Maya's upgrades, real parts, real tuning. The ghost takes calculated risks. Controlled aggression.
The Act 2 version thought it had everything figured out. You can see it in the data — the confidence. The certainty. The way it commits to every line like there's no possibility of being wrong.
You know what came after that certainty. The Fall. The loss. The emptiness of learning that knowing everything isn't the same as understanding anything.
You catch the Act 2 ghost on the back straight. Clean pass. Surgical.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: That version thought they knew everything.
The Act 2 ghost fades. You're alone on the track for a moment. Just you and the sound of the engine and the road.
New ghost. Act 3 data.
This one hurts to watch.

The Act 3 ghost is driving a worse car. The beater. The one you were left with when everything was taken. The ghost is slower — not from lack of skill but from lack of everything else. No grip. No power. No support.
But the ghost is fighting. God, it's fighting. Every corner is a war between will and physics. Every straight is a prayer to an engine that barely wants to run.
The Act 3 version didn't know if it would make it. You can see it in the data — the hesitations. The moments where the throttle dips for just a fraction of a second. Not braking. Doubting.
You run alongside the Act 3 ghost. Not racing it. Not yet. Just... being there. The way nobody was there then.
Then you pass. Gently. Like lifting a weight off your own shoulders.
The Act 3 ghost fades.
Silence.
No radio. No commentary. No one tells you what you already know.
Just the Driver, alone on the track. The engine note steady. The line perfect. Not perfect like a computer — perfect like a human who has made every possible mistake and learned from each one.
You cross the finish line. No ghost to beat this time. Just the empty track and the knowledge that you're here. You made it.

lines.speaker: Driver
lines.text: I'm not faster than I was.
A breath. The engine ticks.

lines.speaker: Driver
lines.text: I'm better than I was.
